title: 110_hr853
content: The "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The Congress finds that improving population health and reducing medical costs requires preventive methods. Organizations in the US need more public health professionals as there are only about 6,000 board-certified preventive medicine physicians. Many healthcare costs are spent on avoidable chronic conditions, yet the number of preventive medicine programs and students has decreased. The number of preventive medicine residency programs and individuals pursuing preventive medicine has significantly decreased in recent years. Preventive medicine physicians are uniquely trained to serve patients and communities, and a strong public health system requires a strong preventive medicine workforce. Loan payment assistance is provided for preventive medicine physicians. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may pay up to $20,000 of medical education loans for eligible preventive medicine physicians who receive board certification in preventive medicine between fiscal years 2008 and 2012. Application for payment must be submitted to the Secretary as required. Definitions in this section include an "eligible preventive medicine physician" as a physician certified in preventive medicine from 2008 to 2012, a "medical education loan" as a loan for medical school expenses, and a "school of medicine" as defined in the Public Health Service Act. The term "school of medicine" is defined in the Public Health Service Act as a medical education institution. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 to implement this section. SEC. 4. WELLNESS PROGRAM EMPLOYER CREDIT. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section for a Wellness Program Employer Credit. The Wellness Program Employer Credit allows eligible employers to receive a tax credit of 25% of expenses incurred to develop and implement a qualified wellness program, with a maximum credit of $200 per qualified employee. The Wellness Program Employer Credit provides a tax credit to eligible employers who develop and implement a qualified wellness program and keep accurate records of employee participation. The qualified wellness program for eligible employers is developed and implemented in consultation with a wellness program expert to ensure compliance and privacy protection for participants. Health risk assessments are conducted as part of the program. The qualified wellness program for eligible employers includes health risk assessments, preventive services, and counseling sessions on smoking and obesity. The qualified wellness program offers annual counseling sessions and seminars on smoking, obesity, stress management, physical fitness, nutrition, substance abuse, depression, mental health, heart disease, and maternal and infant health. The qualified wellness program covers counseling sessions and seminars on various health topics including substance abuse, depression, mental health, heart disease, and maternal and infant health for full-time employees of eligible employers. Qualified participants must include at least 50% of the employer's full-time employees. The qualified wellness program covers counseling sessions and seminars on health topics for full-time employees of eligible employers. A qualified employee is a full-time employee who participates in the employer's wellness program. A qualified participant must engage in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs. A qualified participant in a wellness program must engage in at least 2 annual preventive services and undergo a health risk assessment during the taxable year. This provision does not apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2012. The eligible employer must develop and implement a qualified wellness program during the taxable year. This section does not apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2012. Amendments to the tax code include the addition of a wellness program employer credit. The tax code is amended to include a wellness program employer credit under section 45O(a). The tax code is amended to include a wellness program participant credit under section 25E, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. The tax code allows a $200 credit against the tax for the taxable year for qualified employees who are full-time employees and participants in the employer's wellness program. Qualified participants for the $200 tax credit must be full-time employees of the eligible employer and actively engage in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs offered by the qualified wellness program, along with undergoing a health risk assessment during the taxable year. The eligible employer must develop and implement a qualified wellness program for full-time employees to qualify for the $200 tax credit. Participants must engage in preventive services, undergo a health risk assessment, and be determined by the employer. The eligible employer must develop and implement a qualified wellness program that conducts health risk assessments for participants to qualify for the $200 tax credit. The qualified wellness program must protect participant privacy, conduct health risk assessments, offer preventive services, and provide counseling on smoking, obesity, stress management, and physical fitness. Qualified wellness programs must offer seminars on smoking, obesity, stress management, physical fitness, nutrition, substance abuse, depression, mental health, heart disease, and maternal and infant health, with at least 50% of full-time employees eligible to participate. Qualified wellness programs must cover topics such as smoking, obesity, stress management, physical fitness, nutrition, substance abuse, depression, mental health, heart disease, and maternal and infant health, with at least 50% of full-time employees eligible to participate. Eligible employers must develop and implement these programs and keep accurate records of employee participation in preventive services and other programs. Qualified wellness programs must cover various topics with at least 50% of full-time employees eligible to participate. Eligible employers must develop, implement, and keep accurate records of employee participation in preventive services and other programs. This section does not apply after December 31, 2012. The amendment regarding the Wellness program participant credit applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007.
